repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: Unnecessarily anecdotal wording.

Solution: Adjust wording while delivering the same message.

comment_data.body:
I agree that starting this section with a "how not to do it" is not ideal, and I thought about this but didn't have time to rearrange it.

I do think we should keep some language that mildly discourages `setup` "except when other approach A or B is not applicable".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
Is this part at the end of the added paragraph enough to serve as discouragement?

> Beware that this requires users to call it even if using default configuration is enough for them.

The point here is that requiring to create global variables before loading plugin can achieve some goals of combined `setup()`. The problem is that `vim.g` route might become confusing for newcomers, as it requires specific time before loading plugin to set them (I've personally been there).

The combined `setup()` is a reasonable and a common design choice specifically for mentioned conditions (enable only part of plugin, like single module, and customize initialization). Plus it can have more user-friendly behavior of typo validation (which is mentioned in `*lua-plugin-config*`), but I didn't want to include that to not appear as biased.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
> The problem is that `vim.g` route might become confusing for newcomers, as it requires specific time before loading plugin to set them

This can easily be avoided by implementing `|lua-plugin-lazy|` properly.
The only time I've ever encountered this issue was when someone unnecessarily tried to lazy-load my plugin + the config using lazy.nvim.

> enable only part of plugin, like single module, and customize initialization

Both of these are also possible with strictly separated configuration and initialization.
I suppose if you're referring to a use case where you combine multiple plugins in one package (like what nvim-lspconfig used to be before `vim.lsp.config`; or your specific use case of mini.nvim installed as a whole bundle), `setup` entrypoints for each "module" can be a reasonable API.

> it can have more user-friendly behavior of typo validation

This is only true if your plugin has lots of separate `vim.g` variables and uses them directly.
If you have a `vim.g` table that is read from internally via a function and/or set externally via a function, there's no difference in the complexity of validation logic, except for perhaps a small amount of boilerplate.
Or better - implement typo validation in a health check. Then you avoid unnecessary overhead.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
> Both of these are also possible with strictly separated configuration and initialization.

Nothing in this PR is intended to contradict that. The goal is to remove unnecessarily anecdotal wording while still mentioning particular use cases where combined `setup()` is appropriate.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
Then it seems redundant to mention `setup` as an option in its current form, since your proposed change doesn’t highlight use cases where it’s truly beneficial. Additionally, it doesn’t discourage cargo culting, which remains a concern.

In my opinion, simply adding "also" is too subtle. As it stands, the paragraph could easily be misinterpreted as: "using setup is a better option if you want users to explicitly enable only part of the plugin’s functionality or adjust the initialization process."

It would make sense to explicitly state when `setup` is appropriate, and to warn against adopting it without clear justification.

Here's a rough proposal:

> On the other hand, a single `setup(opts)` function that couples configuration and initialization
> may be useful in specific cases, such as:
>
> - Customizing complex initialization, where there is a significant risk of configuration being applied after initialization.
> - Allowing users to enable plugin functionality that should not be initialized
>   automatically (instead of requiring them to opt out).
>
> Keep in mind that this approach requires users to call `setup` in order to use your plugin,
> even if they are happy with the default configuration.
> Consider carefully whether your plugin truly benefits from coupling configuration and initialization before adopting this pattern.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
> Here's a rough proposal:
> 
> > On the other hand, a single `setup(opts)` function that couples configuration and initialization
> > may be useful in specific cases, such as:
> > 
> > * Customizing complex initialization, where there is a significant risk of configuration being applied after initialization.
> > * Allowing users to enable plugin functionality that should not be initialized
> >   automatically (instead of requiring them to opt out).
> > 
> > Keep in mind that this approach requires users to call `setup` in order to use your plugin,
> > even if they are happy with the default configuration.
> > Consider carefully whether your plugin truly benefits from coupling configuration and initialization before adopting this pattern.

Sure. If no "newcomers" mention and after replacing "even if they are happy with the default configuration" -> "even if using default configuration is enough for them", then it sounds good. @justinmk, does this sound good?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body: Glad to have found a common ground :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
Pushed a change after making descriptions a bit more compact. I can not stress this enough: there is no intention of undermining the suggestion. Making built-in help as concise as possible is usually a welcome approach.

I guess one thing that might be considered "confrontational" here is that I removed the "truly benefits" to just "benefits", as there is already a "Consider carefully". Again - not the intention, trying to reduce wording while preserving the message (and its degree).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_data.body:
LGTM!

> that I removed the "truly benefits" to just "benefits", as there is already a "Consider carefully". 

That's perfectly reasonable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -121,18 +121,8 @@ In the user's config:
 ==============================================================================
 Initialization                                               *lua-plugin-init*
 
-Newcomers to Lua plugin development will often put all initialization logic in
-a single `setup` function, which takes a table of options.
-If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
-your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.

comment_regular_data.body:
This "adjustment" [does not deliver the same message](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29073#discussion_r1618653016).
Furthermore, it implies that it is not possible [it is!] - or it's somehow harder to achieve [it's not!] - for users to be able to explicitly enable only part of a plugin's functionality without using `setup(opts)` function for both initialization and configuration.

> This "adjustment" [does not deliver the same message](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29073#discussion_r1618653016).

It does deliver the same message of "separate configuration and initialization whenever you can" while not going down the route of using anecdotes.

> Furthermore, it implies that it is not possible [it is!] - or it's somehow harder to achieve [it's not!] - for users to be able to explicitly enable only part of a plugin's functionality without using `setup(opts)` function for both initialization and configuration.

Let's not go down the route of what it might or might not imply. There are much more to be said in this area about the current wording and it will (as always) go down as "no, I don't see it, you just imagine things".

My goal here is to be as neutral in wording as possible while still being helpful. Is using "... is _also_ a common practice" alleviate the concern of possible implications?

> It does deliver the same message of "separate configuration and initialization whenever you can" while not going down the route of using anecdotes.

this is absolutely not the message the original text delivered

the original part also said (and quite directly, not much room for interpretation here) that plugins should be initialized without the user having to call anything
and you completely remove that part

In my opinion it's completely useless (and kinda disrespectful) to bring this up again after there were lengthy discussions about this in the issue from justin to create this and also in the pr which added it

> My goal here is to be as neutral in wording as possible while still being helpful.

That is simply not the case in this PR.

@echasnovski your repeated interventions:

- https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices/issues/5
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29026
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29073#discussion_r1618366751
- And now this PR

especially after community review and acceptance, come across as dismissive of my contributions and efforts. This kind of behavior is discouraging and feels unnecessarily adversarial and confrontational, rather than collaborative or constructive.

[As mentioned previously](https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices/issues/5#issuecomment-2131604780), if these negative interactions persist, I will block any future interaction with you.

> especially after community review and acceptance, come across as dismissive of my contributions and efforts. This kind of behavior is discouraging and feels unnecessarily adversarial and confrontational, rather than collaborative or constructive.

Please take into account that merging initial PR often doesn't mean that all work in the area is automatically finished. Expressing some valuable Lua plugin development advice in a structured manner is no easy task and you did a good job, nobody denies that. However, anything can and is expected to be [incrementally improved in the follow up PRs](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/29073#issuecomment-3243409940).

The comment about this particular change was hidden as outdated very long time before the merged and was not marked as resolved by the core team. Making a follow up PR for more visible and dedicated discussions is a reasonable course of actions in such situations because I didn't want to block #29073 as a whole.

> [As mentioned previously](https://github.com/nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices/issues/5#issuecomment-2131604780), if these negative interactions persist, I will block any future interaction with you.

Please take into account that in *all* links (and if I remember correctly, ever) it was not me who initiated direct interactions:
- I (indirectly via addressing to the every member of an org) was asked on Matrix to leave thoughts about nvim-neorocks/nvim-best-practices#5.
- #29073 and this PR are contributions to the public project I care about and within which can leave comments with my opinions.
- #29026 didn't have any interactions at all.

The current version makes it much clearer that there's a need to separate init and config, while the proposed version suggests that not following this separation is the "common practice" (so does that mean I should actually follow it?). More importantly, the current wording explains *why* this separation is necessary:
```
If you do this, users will be forced to call this function in order to use
your plugin, even if they are happy with the default configuration.
```
To me, this goes beyond a wording adjustment and actually shifts the semantics quite significantly.

> The current version makes it much clearer that there's a need to separate init and config, while the proposed version suggests that not following this separation is the "common practice" (so does that mean I should actually follow it?). 

Only if plugin authors have specific outlined conditions met in their plugins. There is nothing indicating that it is better to use, just mentioned as a viable alternative.

> More importantly, the current wording explains _why_ this separation is necessary:

My reading is that starting with "Strictly separated configuration and smart initialization allow your plugin to work out of the box" is enough to indicate that it is the main suggestion which is advised to follow. While being shorter and to the point, which is usually what is welcome in built-in help.

Does adding a more neutral note about combined `setup()` shortcomings help here?

---

Anyway, I'll wait for @justinmk to weigh in, because this seems to go out of hand.

Perhaps there should be separate sections of the document? Each can present one way to handle configuration and initialization and the pros and cons of that approach?

I can't imagine a good result of trying to please both sides of this debate in a single section, and this debate has been going on a long time, for this PR and earlier.

Since both methods are common in the wild, the built-in docs should discuss both. If the ecosystem eventually settles on one approach—even a new one—the docs can be updated.

tl;dr—nobody is helped by these docs being a constant tug of war game.

@echasnovski please don't deflect.

You claim you did not initiate direct interactions, but your repeated PRs and comments (not only on GitHub) specifically addressed my work and its direction, both here and previously. Even if not all comments were direct replies, the pattern and timing of your interventions, especially immediately after my contributions were requested and again after they were merged, cannot be ignored.

The argument that "merging initial PRs doesn’t mean all work is finished" is fair in general, but in this case, you continually pushed your own agenda.

You state you "didn’t want to block #29073 as a whole," yet your follow-up actions, as well as #29026, attempted to override or redirect it, which feels dismissive and undermining.

I want to reiterate that this pattern makes it difficult for me to feel welcomed or respected as a contributor.
This is behavior I have not observed from any other contributor.
If this kind of behavior continues, I will have no choice but to block further communication.

I hope you will reflect on this and consider a more constructive and respectful approach going forward.

I have said all that I have to say to you in this PR.

> I hope you will reflect on this and consider a more constructive and respectful approach going forward.
> 
> I have said all that I have to say to you in this PR.

Yes, of course, I will reflect. Thank you so much for your detailed feedback :+1:
I can't approve this PR as I'm not a member of the Nvim org. But in its current form, I agree that it's an improvement.

title: docs: adjust *lua-plugin-init* wording
